November 10, 2018 at 11:56 am
what GPA is needed for top law schools (social sciences major, unhooked)? I've looked at schools' averages, but I'm wondering how much of a difference going to Princeton makes. Is > 3.85 safe?

Response from Pablo:

Yes, that’s great! I mean, I think that would probably be safe at any good school. From the good friends I know who have gone to Harvard, Yale, etc., I think a ~3.7 from Princeton seems to be fine as well, though the LSAT plays a pretty important role (for better or for worse). Other GPAs might also be perfectly fine as well, this is just completely based on my very limited experience.

Of course, a higher GPA is genuinely not everything. Although this doesn’t mean you should not take your classes seriously, but the goal is ultimately to put forward the most compelling app you can. For everyone out there, my recommendation would be to just do your best GPA-wise and LSAT-wise, be involved in the community, and make sure to build strong relationships with professors. Maybe one day I will be proven wrong, but I believe that if you are genuinely passionate about the law—whatever that means to you—you will end up in the right place—whether that’s a Top 5 Law School or elsewhere—and you WILL succeed. Much love, law school candidates! <3

How to deal with hookup culture/ expectations of sex in relationships if you’re not that into it? (Aka maybe asexual/ need to know someone super well before even considering it)

Response from Marty McFly:

The main thing is to be confident in your decision. If you mean that your partner is pressuring you into stuff, that’s not ideal, and you should talk to them. They probably mean well, so just explain that it makes you uncomfortable. If that doesn’t work, you probably shouldn’t be hanging out with them. I’m guessing you’re talking about ‘societal expectations’ where it’s like ‘oh you’ve gotta be constantly getting it to be in a good relationship.’ I def get that but you’ll also really regret making decisions on that basis. Believe it or not, there are no authorities that patrol this. In fact, no one even knows/judges you based on such minor things in reality. The very useless sounding advice I’ll give you is just don’t do anything you’re uncomfortable with and after a little time you’ll realize that everything is fine and that you were worried about nothing. It’s honestly not a bad way to find out if you’re boyfriend/girlfriend is in it for different reasons. Admittedly, it can be made a tad more difficult if you have friends that all live their lives another way, but I’m sure they’ll support you however you wanna do things.

Your presence is a gift. Everything about you is worth it. I have no idea who you are, but I am so incredibly proud of you for just getting out of bed on any given day and facing the world, because personhood is damn difficult and our shoulders were never meant to bear a lot of the heaviness that lands on us anyway. I am so grateful for you.

November 9, 2018 at 3:57 pm
advice for cap bickering? or just bickering in general?

Response from Katara:

I’d say above all do be yourself. Remember its not like a interview for a job or anything, you’re talking to other college kids probably your age who just want good people in their club to eat meals with and stuff. So putting on a show/ trying to be someone you’re not is probably not the best option because ppl can see right through it. For cap specifically you can search bar for details (cap bicker nick) but I know there bicker involves games and activities, so try to be “fun and outgoing” but also not dominate conversations or rub people the wrong way. That kind of goes for any club, if you’re bickering somewhere where you don’t know a ton of people, you want to have memorable conversations so people remember you. I also would ask members you know in the club specifically about the bicker process and cap itself, they’ll probably be more than happy to tell you.

But also going off that, bicker is decided by a bunch of college kids who really don’t know anything about you in the long run so don’t take anything that happens (good or bad) to heart. 

Response from Kronk:

Yup, agreed with all of the above - being yourself and trying to be friendly are the key pieces of advice imo. For cap specifically, I know other members like it when someone bickering genuinely shows or has shown interest in the club, whether that’s through coming to pre-bicker events (coming soon, I believe), coming to nights out, or just having a really good why cap? answer. The key word in that sentence is genuine. If you’re a soph and already have friends in the club to ask questions to, then great; if not, then definitely come to events and talk to members and ask questions too.

Cap bicker is a mixture of games and conversations, mostly leaning towards games. A lot of members get really reallly into designing their games and trying to make it fun and just get super bummed when a bickeree doesn’t seem like they’re into it/not participating. Nothing is designed or allowed to be uncomfortable and if something does make you uncomfortable, you should report it to an officer immediately, but for the most part, a lot of members are trying to see if you can let loose a little and enjoy yourself. That being said, Katara is right in that you shouldn’t overdo it and be the only person in the circle talking the entire time. Another thing is that a lot of games or conversations will involve asking bickerees to tell us a story or something interesting about themselves, and some people unfortunately come up with some pretty inappropriate things that don’t sit well with a large audience, so just be mindful of that too.

And at the end of the day, bicker is a process in which a small group of people get to talk to you for an average of <7 minutes each in an unnatural environment for a cumulative total of less than a few hours. So it truly has 0 basis in determining anything real about anyone - so just have fun with it however you can

November 9, 2018 at 2:40 pm
overwhelmed frosh :( I feel like I don't have enough time to do schoolwork AND apply to summer opportunities AND extracurriculars AND have balanced mental health. help?

Response from Marty McFly:

It’s very likely that you don’t. I guess just organize everything in a sustainable way. So be really real with yourself about how much time you need for each thing, and look at your schedule and ask yourself where it will fit. Like plan out an entire week such that you have enough time set aside for everything you want to do (with an appropriate amount of wiggle room). And don’t forget to factor in time that’s wasted walking, eating, getting distracted talking to someone, etc. Is it something you could/want to do every week? If the answer is yes, then you just need to maintain that level of organization. Keep track of all your long term responsibilities in one place, your weekly responsibilities in another place, and make yourself a daily list of things that need to get done that day. Once that’s done, trust yourself. Assume that nothing needs to get done besides what’s on the list, and forget about everything else. If you find yourself with free time, you move on to things that are due later. If you’re being as productive as you predicted, you’ll be totally on top of stuff. 

If you can’t to that, then you’re gonna have to get rid of some stuff. Think about your priorities and what you can afford to drop/pdf/quit. It’s not very likely that everything you’re doing here is worth taking a substantial hit to mental health, so don’t compromise on that. If you need help deciding, talk to PAAs/RCAs/advisors/resubmit with what you’re considering dropping and we can try to advise. As far as I know, there is no third option.

November 9, 2018 at 1:35 pm

I’m really just bad at chemistry labs? I do all the steps correctly but my results just never turn out right and I can never seem to titrate to the right endpoint. Advice and will this affect my grade if I’m writing all the reports otherwise?

Response from Kronk:

l m a o one time in orgo lab, my yield was like 1% and I asked my TA if that was enough for the lab check and he just laughed at me and said “not if you want to pass”. 

but yeah same here when I was in chem lab. I think titrations are especially ridiculous because you’ll think you’ve reached the endpoint, you’ll ask the TA for a check, they’ll tell you titrate a little more, and then boom you’ve overtitrated. I think as long as you get at least some semblance of the right product, you’re fine for the lab - it’s more of the analysis that they care about than the actual lab performance. So in the write up, as long as you’re answering all their questions, doing their calculations, and then in the discussion, talking about sources of error & how your results would have been different with better titrations, then you’ll be fine on the lab grade. I wouldn’t be too worried about how “good” the physical results are, it’s more about how you think about it. if you fuck up a lab too much to the point that you couldn’t do the lab, the lab TA will let you know and you’ll have to redo it lol (have seen this happen before)

so, freshman here already going through a crisis of major: im currently an AB student (projected EEB major), but im yet again considering CEE. would it be worth it to switch to bse and try out cee and then switch back to ab soph year if i change my mind? Also, im not currently enrolled in a math class (though i have taken BC w/ a 5 and took a multivariable course), would i have to take multi again or could i place into lin algebra?

Response from Opal:

Seeing as BSE has a lot more requirements, if you are seriously considering CEE, it might be worth making the switch now. There is a good amount of overlap between BSE and EEB prereqs - you have to take chem for both, you have to take physics for both, and you have already knocked out the EEB math requirement with your calc AP. This means that if you do CEE for a semester or two and then decide that you want to go back to EEB, you really only have to squeeze in those two intro EEB classes (or one if you have AP bio credit) and a stats class before junior fall, which is doable. You still have time to explore and solidify your interests, but start tackling those BSE classes if there is a real possibility of you ending up with CEE. Also, for your last question, you could always take a math placement test - there are probably students who place straight into linear algebra every year, but I will say that the majority of people who come into Princeton with a background in multivariable calculus still take MAT 201/203 anyway, because those classes go into more depth than most high schools do. Best of luck with everything!

November 9, 2018 at 12:57 pm
how do acapella auditions work for girls? how many songs do you prepare? do I have basicaly no change as a sophomore?

Response from Opal:

Auditions are pretty formulaic across the board. You start off by singing some scales to warm up your voice and give some indication of your vocal range. Then, they will ask you to do some pitch-matching exercises (they play a series of notes and you sing them back), pitch-finding exercises (they play a series of chords and ask you to sing back the top, middle, or bottom note), and maybe some swells (you sing a note as softly and as loudly as you can). There may be a couple of groups that will also give you sheet music and test your sight-singing ability, but that is not super common. Finally, you get a chance to perform your prepared piece - one verse and chorus of one song should be enough. And then you are done! If you get a callback, they usually teach you songs during that process, so there is really no need for you to prepare more than one song beforehand, but I also do not see how it would hurt to have multiple songs up your sleeve. One time, I got too sick to hit the high notes of my prepared song on the day of a musical audition, so I walked into the room and sang an alto-range piece instead, because I also happened to know it well. Anyway, as a sophomore, you definitely still have a shot with basically any a cappella group. Kudos for putting yourself out there, and good luck with your auditions!
November 9, 2018 at 12:42 pm
Best PDF classes for lazy seniors that are also not a complete waste of time?

Response from Opal:

Other contributors should add on, but I really feel the need to at least briefly plug theatre classes on this blog. Setting aside the fact that I have yet to take one at Princeton, all of the ones offered this spring are highly reviewed, and almost all of them are either PDF-only or PDF-able, and more importantly, I seriously believe that getting exposure to theatre will change your life. Whether you take an intro to acting or an atelier about puppets and movement or a course on costume and set design, you will learn so much about how to navigate the intersections of reality, identity, and expression, and you will take those skills and understandings with you wherever you go, long after the class is over. I am not even going to throw in a cheesy “All the world’s a stage” at this point, because theatre does not make you more performative or artificial - on the contrary, it forces you to engage deeply with truth and essentials, both within yourself and within the wider universe. I know I am waxing overdramatic, but a) I am a theatre kid, so deal with it, and b) it truly commands that much power. You describe yourself as a “lazy senior,” and you will absolutely be in control of how much or how little work you put into a theatre class, but I will just leave you with this: There is a distinct possibility that you will end up not wanting to hold back your effort!

November 9, 2018 at 12:22 pm
How to deal with existential exhaustion?

Response from Opal:

Sure, existence has no extrinsic significance, and any meaning that we could possibly ascribe to our lives is constructed, yet I do not believe that to be discouraging in the slightest. I know very little about philosophy, but I think that nihilism can be comforting and even optimistic. You see, the universe is the ultimate open-world sandbox game, and there is no end goal - there are only achievements. Some of those include making yourself happy. Some of those include making others happy. Nothing actually matters, which I see as the best reason of all to be a force for light and joy. The atoms in all of our bodies are borrowed ones, and they belong to us for a breathtakingly evanescent window of time before dissipating back into a sea of entropy - which renders life all the more precious, which renders our temporary sentience and consciousness and ability to explore the cosmos all the more exciting and rare. You are, always have been, and always will be intimately connected to everything else, but only now - now - now - do you have the opportunity to make sense of it. Like I said, all meaning is constructed, but it does not have to be artificial, because you get to be the one who imbues it with power. If you say “Let there be light,” then there will be light. Now get out there, shake off your exhaustion like a coat of dust, and make someone smile before the day is over.

re: kernighan vs dondero. war stories from the front lines?

Response from Sushi’s friend:

As for war stories, at the risk of sounding like a fanboy, Kernighan is a living breathing piece of comp sci history. He is the K in K&R C, one of the seminal books on the language, also the k in awk which is useful for processing data at the command line. He’s worked with some of the greatest at Bell labs and also taught some of the smarty pants making waves now. In this way, his lectures are war stories from the front lines of computing and how we got to where we are today.

November 9, 2018 at 9:29 am

how do i deal with crippling loneliness? it feels like everyone is already friends with each other and im just an outsider doing psets alone, eating alone, spending my free time in my room doing nothing

Response from Scarlett O’Hara:

I’m so sorry you’re feeling this way. You are definitely not the only person:For proof that not “everyone is already friends with each other”, please look up “lonely” in the searchbar. That one keyword brings up 83 results (and think about all the synonyms for “lonely”, so there must be at least a couple hundred posts about feeling this way). Most groups that look like close friends are not even that close (for proof, see all the posts where people are sad that they’re not satisfied in their friendships). 

Is the problem that you feel like you don’t have enough friends or that you feel like you don’t hang out with them enough? We’ve answered many variations of both of these questions, so use the searchbar for a wide variety of advice. If you’re freshman, please know that almost every freshman has this phase or recurring feeling. Whatever your year is, the number one ways to make friends are asking to do psets with other people, putting yourself out there and texting acquaintances/classmates you talk to if they wanna grab a meal or go to an event, joining clubs. If you’re eating alone and notice someone you kind of know or have met who is also eating alone, don’t be afraid to ask if you can join: Even though it’s totally fine (and sometimes actually really nice) to eat alone, you’re not the only person who’s eating alone and wishes there were other people with them. Last year, none  of my good friends from my res college liked eating breakfast or our schedules didn’t line up, so I at breakfast alone most days (which I actually enjoy bc it’s hard to make convos when you’re groggy lol) UNTIl mutual friends that I’d met a few times realized that we were all eating alone when we could’ve been eating together. Basically my point is that if you look/ask around, you’ll see that there are a ton of other people doing things alone (either by choice or bc they’re lonely) and most of them are totally open to making/strengthening friendships! 

The hardest part of getting out of the loneliness is making the first new friend, once you’ve made one move, the following ones are so much easier! Please believe me when I say that, even though people with a lot of friends stand out more bc they’re louder and take up more space, there are so many other people who are lonely or eager to make more good friends. If I didn’t touch on anything that helps you out, check out past posts about loneliness that so many rtp contributors have answered. If your loneliness is really crippling you, don’t be afraid to make a CPS appointment bc maybe it’s part of a larger issue that needs to be addressed by a caring, knowledgeable professional. Even though I don’t know you, I care about your well-being, so please seek help if you feel you might need it. Love you OP and I wish you the best of luck,  please trust me when I say you’re not alone and it does get better.

from sushi’s friend

For all the readers asking about COS 324 next semester. Other options are ELE 364, COS 424, ELE 435, MAT 490. From friends, ELE 364 is basically “machine learning for future consultants” - lots of memorization and no real programming or theoretical component. From previous RTP posts, COS 424 offered in the spring is seems to be “guide to programming with Python ML packages” (maybe Tensorflow, PyTorch, etc (sushi comment: scikit learn i think)). COS 324 is the theory ML class if you’re scared of MAT 490 (like me!). Not sure but from hearsay maybe more intense than 435?

(sushi comment: also ORF 350, which is offered next spring at 8:30 am. It was a good class under Han Liu, but we aren’t sure how it will be under the new prof)

Yes, it’s still Prof. Adams teaching it. Prof. Adams’s version is “significantly less theoretical than previous [Hazan/Singer] versions of the course.” It’s still theoretical.

Prereqs:
ORF 309 - didn’t take, doable without but probably recommended, been making do with MIT 18.05 lecture notes and PDFs
MAT 201/203 - took 201, know how to take gradients of vector valued functions in   matrix form (look at matrix cookbook) and integrate
MAT 202/204 - took 202, 202 is enough, just look up properties that you forget
COS 226 - probably so you know how to write “non-trivial programs in Python”

Might be helpful, with this background I’m a tad above the median after midterms (Prof gives stats for every assn). Also, for some reason a bunch of grad students took this course this semester (>25% of the class estimated), not sure how that affects things.

Lecture:
   - Prof. Adams writes derivations of results used to construct machine learning algos on the blackboard and
   - shows demos, they’re pretty good

Assignments:
 - Takes me ~8-9 hours/week (due every 2 weeks)
 - 5-6 problems usually, mixed theoretical/coding (they’re here: https://www.cs.princeton.edu/courses/archive/fall18/cos324/)
 - Programming generally asks you to build some ML algo from scratch (e.g. MLE regression, neural network)
 - Theoretical problems are a mixed bag: proving/showing/calculating probability/optimization/linear results
 - Median started around 93 and seems to be dropping each assn

Precepts:
   - All the preceptors this sem know their shit and how to explain pretty well, Jad and Farhan are probably the best
   - Covers foundation material (prereqs minus programming)
   - Like 217 precepts in terms of help with HW, maybe a few notches less since there’s so much foundation required for ML

Midterm:
   - Tests understanding of theoretical aspects of course
   - 6 questions, 90 minutes
   - Given one practice exam, was pretty fair, but hard
   - Median of weighted grade percents from HW1, HW2, midterm: 78

Piazza:
   - Not as lit as 217/226/326, response time anywhere from ~1 day to a few hours generally

TLDR: It’s a good course for what it’s meant to do.

Response from Scarlett O’Hara:

I’d say drop it responsibly, so give a notice that you’d like to drop in *reasonable time frame* so that your responsibilities can be passed on to another member or shared by other existing officers. That’s a lot of clubs to be involved with so you’ve definitely earned the right to drop a few if you’re not thrilled

November 9, 2018 at 12:39 am

I struggle with pdfing classes every semester. I always tell myself to pdf if I get under a certain score, but once pdf starts I start telling myself not to pdf... because I don't want the work I've done to go to waste, getting a P still seems pretty stressful (I would put the same effort into it to make sure I get the P), the possibility of raising my gpa if I'm lucky is enticing. But if I don't pdf, I end up getting an OK grade that lowers my gpa anyway. I would appreciate some advice :(

Response from Scarlett O’Hara:

This has been in the inbox for a little while, so I guess we’re all a little unsure of what to advise.  

Since you’ve already seen that not pdfing a class after contemplating it only gets you an ok grade that lowers your gpa, I think you’ve proven to yourself to trust in your first pdf-instinct and not second-guess. Since this is a recurring problem for you, you might need to change strategies to avoid this problem in the future: maybe select courses based on whether or not you’ll pdf, instead of debating whether to pdf while you’re taking it, start the course with the mindset of your course of action. That way you’re not starting off dedicating so much time that you feel guilty “letting the work go to waste” but you can still be conscious of your efforts to get a P. You definitely should not put the same amount of effort in to get an A as to get a P; if you really think a class requires equal effort to get an A as to get a C, then you’re pdfing the wrong class lol. You’ve gotta practice some tough love and really be honest with yourself about how well you think you can perform in a class. I would be more upset with myself for lowering my gpa again than for missing out on the possibility of raising my gpa tbh, but maybe that’s just me.
